subject: Re: [junit] fundamental questions on JUnit
msgSnippet: ... You don t have to change the return value of the method to be able to test it.  But if you want to, go ahead. I think that a testing tool can suggest you
messageBody:
>>(It is 'against the rules' to change the design of them to return
>>values - a testing tool should not force code changes.)
>
> What's wrong with forcing production code to change only to make it more
> testable?

You don't have to change the return value of the method to be able to
test it. But if you want to, go ahead.

I think that a testing tool can suggest you to change your code but
shouldn't force you to do it. You - and not the testing tool - are the
one knowing what the code should do. You shouldn't for example be
forced to change the access specifiers of a class to please the testing
tool.

> Testability is a good quality to have -- and many times
> it accidently improves the design.

It's hopefully not "accidental" :-) If your tests are easy to write,
it's the sign that your classes have a loose coupling and high cohesion,
which is the sign of a good design.

-Vladimir
